I know I'm late to this, but I have an observation. Our eyes seriously override our directional hearing ability. When I hear birdsong in woodland and I look in the perceived direction I rarely see the bird, even with prolonged looking/listening, but if I close my eyes for a few seconds and listen I can almost immediately pinpoint the source, then I look in that direction and the bird is seen within a small area; with eyes open it can take minutes to do the same location.

The part where Destin talks about "why Dogs Tilt their Heads" I think is at least partially inaccurate.
Dogs tilt their head when you are talking to them because they are trying to understand what you are saying and they are not getting it (just like humans do sometimes).
I think this is a better reason partly due to an article in National Geographic a while back where they did a story on the wolves in and around Yellowstone National Park. In the article the author was watching some wolf pups playing on an icy pond with a chunk of snow or ice. They would knock it around and chase after it. At one point it went to the edge and one of the pups bit it into pieces and the other pups tilted their heads while looking at the other pup that did the dirty deed. To me they just could not get the reason why the pup would do that or what just happened so they tilted their heads in a sort of 'wonder' or 'confusion'.

Interestingly, people do a little bit of that dog thingy, too. Since you can't resolve the front-back ambiguity with sounds that don't have many spectral cues, especially if they are of low frequency, in that case you actually have to turn your head to get a reading. And we do. In particular for loud, surprising noises (part of the startle reflex) but otherwise as well.

This is why head tracked binaural is considerably better than the static version. We don't have all of the integration in place for it, yet, but I've heard it in research settings where the capture/synthesis is done in high order ambisonics (HOA) or wavefield synthesis (WFS) and then rendered down to binaural using a HRTF model which rotates with your head in real time. The results are staggering. Especially with a model derived from your own pinnae/head/shoulders, you can even get auditory parallax: you can often hear the distance of the source.

I think you are leaving out vestiges of echolocation that our brains may be employing. The "horizontal" plane has far more objects for the sound to bounce off of that your auditory complex can use to help triangulate the source of a sound. The "vertical" plane has fewer objects. Try your experiment with trees growing horizontally and see which plane is easier to discern useful information from.

The brain does a lot of subconscious processing that is useful for the prefrontal cortex. This is why driving a manual transmission may begin with watching for visual cues like your tachometer, but slowly transitions to auditory cues like the pitch of your engine. You may not be consciously attending to the pitch of the engine, but your auditory cortex is always processing it.

"Mastery" is nothing more than providing your brain a series of data points which it then determines which data points are common to each set and which data points are variable. After thousands of hours, it has conditioned the neurons associated with the task while pruning all the neurons that are superfluous from the task. Take the first time you learn to add 2 + 2. The first time you hear that idea, you hear, see, smell, taste, feel, and think about millions of other things at the same time. Most of your brain cannot distinguish what is pertinent to "2 + 2", but after working through it some more, your brain can begin to break the connections irrelevant to that idea.

You can also look at it like resolving an image. Pixels that cannot be differentiated are "blurry." Each successive viewing of a scene helps provide more information about that pixel. Eventually, that pixel can be resolved after a certain amount of passes into what value it actually holds.

A little reminiscent of quantum mechanics, no? The probability that a particular neuronal path is pertinent to an idea becomes more collapsed the more times that idea is processed. The certainty with which your brain determines the actual state of a system is greater after many passes of that instance.

Why would dog tilt his head? To know where the sound comes from (while literally staring at you)?! They can remember some words but regarding sound - they decode the tone.
The reason why dogs tilt their heads it's their muzzle. If they don't understand what we're trying to tell them, they try to figure this out from our face - but long muzzle partially blocks their view.

For directional hearing, there is also a difference in phase between the sound hitting the left and right ears. In addition to amplitude and frequency content, phase differences also contribute to our ability to  determine direction.

AFAIK, the dogs' heads story is even more complicated: they have to see your TEETH to fully comprehend your emotions (whether you have a grin, or you're smiling etc), and their own NOSE gets in the way, so they have to tilt their heads. There is even a correlation: dogs with bigger noses tend to do it more often / in a more pronounced way. Also, dogs almost never do this head movement when listening to sounds from inanimate sources.

If you get a drone stuck in a tree and you can't use a weapon in that area I have a suggestion. Y'all need a fishing reel with fairly strong line but not too strong, the slingshot, the kind that has the brace on your wrist and the tubing for the stretchy part, couple  ball bearings. Tape the ball bearings together if you need more than one while taping the fishing line to the ball bearings. Push the button on your real so that the line will pull out freely and lay it on the ground.  Use a slingshot to shoot the ball bearings in the air over the tree. If the line catches you may be able to pull pull pull on the tree and the branches until the drone falls down. At least this worked for me once. You can also use a second drone to fly the line over the tree and set down and tie off to something.

Lack of good echo location in the vertical plane is exactly how I played an epic practical joke on a couple of work colleagues over 25 years ago.  A stock boy at our office had a watch with a broken face and he decided to have a little fun.  He sets the watch alarm to, "beep, beep" every hour and hides it in the sales office.  They eventually find it, assume it is the head of engineering that hid it in their office, so they hide it in his office.  Several rounds of this later I was in the office late on a Friday and the head of engineering was trying to find a good hiding place in the sales office.  I looked at the options and told him I could hide it in a way that they would never find it.  The dimensions of the office was approximately 12' X 12' with an 8' ceiling.  I opened up one of the overhead fluorescent lights in the center of the room, removed the cover off of the ballast, placed the watch back side down in the ballast cover and put everything back together and cleaned up any tale tale drop ceiling tile scraps.  Basically the watch used the entire metal back of the light fixture as a sounding board.  No matter how you turned your head the perceived sound position changed; it seemed co come from everywhere.  Over the next couple of weeks the two sales engineers in that office tore the entire office apart.  Piece by piece they systematically removed every piece of furniture, opened up every plug and light switch cover plate and after two years and a complete office renovation never found the watch.  Over two years later one of those sales engineers was promoted to a branch manager position in another city.  We retrieved the watch, replaced the battery and ultimately that watch followed the promoted sales engineer to an air conditioning duct in the bedroom of his new home!!!!!!  Who would have thought you could have over three years of fun from a broken watch!

I think part of the answer for you asking your sister, "How did you know it was up high in the tree?" is that if you've isolated it to a single tree, you know another part of the equation is fixed distance. You are able to intuit how far away a sound is based on how loud you know it SHOULD be when it's close to you. Like when your son let it take off.

Put another way: Your sister was there for initial launch and now has a point of reference for volume at 1 foot away. And she watched it continue until no longer audible, so she would then be able to estimate distance based on that audibility diminishing curve. Therefore isolated the central location, and is able to estimate height based on volume.

That's right. Our hearing is basically two dimensional. Our earholes are essentially in the same horizontal plane. Sounds that come from a direction that is not on our line of sight extended front and back reach one ear slightly sooner than the other so we turn our head toward that direction. Owls, on the other hand, have 3-dimensional hearing because the feathers that form their facial ruff are not symmetrically functional. The ruffs help to channel sound to the ears. on one side the 'channel' is more open to sound from above the line of sight, and on the other, is more open to sound from below. So sound from above reaches the one ear faster; sound from below reaches the other faster.

I had the almost identical problem with a twist.  My wife bought me a cheap drone for my birthday.  I flew it in a local park, but the wind caught it and I lost control.  It was obviously in some trees nearby and I went to look for it.  The propellers still worked and I could hear it.  Now the twist:  I'm totally deaf in my left ear after a hemorrhage about 7 years ago.  Yes, that was a huge problem for me because I have very little directional hearing.  Fortunately my wife was there too, and she finally found the drone in a tree.  It was hard but I was finally able to pull it down with no damage, no shots were fired!

So question? How does the acoustics work with hearing aids?

Very interesting.  My wife had a tumor in her right ear canal and had to have the entire inner ear removed.  She has no hearing in her right ear.  She was fitted with a device called a BAHA (Bone Anchored Hearing Aid) hearing aid.  The doctor implanted a small titanium stud in her skull right behind her right ear.The stud attaches to a small microphone that vibrates.  The vibrations are sent through her skull to the left ear.  The time it takes the sound waves to travel through her skull are about the same as sound waves traveling through air.  So her brain has retrained to hear both sides in only one ear.  It's not perfect, but works pretty darn well.

The video falls apart at the point you advertise your Sound Traveler Channel...

Why? You go over how directional hearing essentially works with just two microphones - for hearing up/down - so hearing in height you explain how the shape of the ear is needed.

With a binaural microphone like from the brand 3Dio the sound is captured at the entry to the auditoral canal, so after the ear shape could "do its magic". But with the headphones/microphone combination you are using the capsule of the microphone is too far out to capture the sound at the point where the ears effect is "applied" to the audio.

So I disagree Destin - the recordings you do for the Sound Traveler IS NOT binaural audio.

I have a severe hearing loss in my right ear from my teen years due to an infection that took out my middle ear bones. So I don't naturally have directional hearing. I was able to get a bone anchored hearing aid that has helped. I came up with an idea that you may be able to develop with your engineering skills. Make a cap that has tiny parabolic microphones mounted around the rim and on top. At each of the locations also place a vibrator as in a cell phone's silent ringer. Have a way to select prerecorded sounds and also a button to record a brief sound in the field that can be stored. Once the sound is selected or recorded a processor "listens" to the ambient noise and compares the sound waves.  When the selected sound is received by the mic's then the processor determines the strongest signal and sends a signal to the vibrator at that mic to help the wearer know the direction of the sound. I know lot's of hunters and nature watchers would pay considerably to regain directional hearing.

This sounds exactly like the time my sister's cat was outside with a thunderstorm coming. She was frantically calling it, and we could HEAR him meowing, but he wouldn't come back to the house. So she and I walked outside, meowing at him, and listening for him to meow back, and following the sound. I located his X/Y location, because I'd walk two feet forward, and then he'd be behind me. After awhile of not seeing him on the ground, I realized I was circling a tree, and so I looked up the tree, only about 10 ft, then down to the ground. No cat. 20 ft up? Back to the ground? No cat. All the way to the top of what was easily a 30 or 40 foot tree, and there was that dumb cat looking down at me over the edge of a bird's nest... I think he learned his lesson, because he spent a very loud thunderstorm and the summer night that followed outside in that bird nest, and stayed there until the next day when Mom could get a tree guy to come out with his tree-climbing gear to get the cat down. :) I think the cat jumped out of his arms at 10 ft up and ran inside, terrified. :D

In the 70's there was a "new thing" everyone was raving about called "dummy head stereo" The idea was that you made a recording with and audibly accurate head that had 2 microphones near the entrance to the ear canal. When the recording was played back with on-ear open head phones, the perception of the listener was of actually being there. There was talk of recording music in this manner but I think the idea fell apart because most people use speakers spaced a distance apart so the experience was under par for these recordings. I do have a recording however made by Sennheiser in the early 1970's that was quite impressive.

People do have vertical hearing ability but it must be trained in youth. Each person has a unique shape ear and this shape alters the frequency response of the hearing in the 5,000 to 15,000 hz range, especially around 10,000hz. This change in response varies with the angle of the incoming sound and so with training one can locate height, specially good for birds whose chirps and songs extend into that range. (you have to train it because people's ears are different shapes)

I once used a tunable notch filter to tune a notch sweeping up through that range (balanced random noise source ie like the sound of the sea in a sea shell) and the sound through headphones seemed to rise and fall in height. On headphones it sounds like the sound source is in the middle of your head but with the height sensitivity activated it rises up to the top of your head by subjective experience.

Thus we do have height locating ability but it is poorly trained in modern people and even left-right horizontal location abilities are rather poor.

Some 50 years ago, my father told me I was wrong when I talked about the time of arrival difference. The military had found out that the ears are insensitive to phase differences of sound wave arrival. The directional sensitivity comes from our skull being a baffle and the perceived amplitude differences along with turning our head give us this sensation. While us humans are insensitive to phase differences, most electronic sensors are very sensitive to phase. Thus, a microphone is not a mechanical or electrical ear simulator.

You ever visited an anacoustic chamber? Designed to completely damp all reflective noise. It's weird, because your voice doesn't bounce off anything, and you sound tinny to yourself. Some people get nauseous. The one I visited was a huge box suspended on damped springs, with 2 one tonne sound proof doors leading in. The floor was wire mesh half way up the box, and the (6) walls were covered in soft wedges, like a proffessional sound booth, but much more space age. You should take your 3D audio experience in one of these. It's the opposite of majestic, but it is wonderfully uncanny.

As a S.C.U.B.A. diver I can recommend the challenge of trying to calculate sound sources underwater. We used to try this with wreck buoys on windy days and we would listen for the clanking chains underwater. Even taking a compass sight on the surface and then navigating a quarter mile at 30-40 ft without surfacing it was rare to find the chain unless the wreck was shallow enough to make out from 40'. Currents move you and the sound of the chain hits both ears almost simultaneously. Certainly too fast for your ear to make a directional determination. This exercise met with a 90% failure rate over several trips.

So here is a crazy thought:
Suppose we perfectly duplicate someone's ears (with silicone rubber mold etc), mount them on a jig at the correct distance to each other and fit microphones inside each. If this person listened at a later time to this recording through headphones, would he/she be able to perceive the vertical position of various sounds, e.g, will the recorded sound carry the required signatures for the brain to do the required decoding?

2 years late: 3d sound with headphones in gaming - Games use an algorithm to simulate how the sound travels and bounces off your ear so you get the 3d effect even if you`re using stereo headphones. It's not perfect as it uses a general model to simulate the ear but the brain adjusts and can identify where sounds are coming from, this was known and used in games from the early 3d games(HL1 engine was groundbreaking when it came out)

I'll go with your theory on humans but disagree with your comparison on dogs.   Dogs aren't humans.   To understand why dogs tilt their heads you first have to understand dogs.   A dog doesn't understand the human language.   They also don't have cognitive thinking.   When dogs learn they use both their eyes and their ears.   We speak a command followed by an action to train them.   After time they recognize the command and then react but they always like the visual cue also.   Take a hot dog bun and put on the end of your nose and notice how things appear less clear.   When a dog doesn't understand a verbal cue they will often tilt their head for a better visual cue around their hotdog bun nose.

@SmarterEveryDay: Our ears are not "exactly" on a well leveled horizontal plane. Meaning from feet or ground up, they are not exactly the same height, e.g one ear is 5' 8" high from ground and the other is 5' 7.9993" from the ground. This minute difference helps the brain with, lets call it, sound depth and positioning perception. This difference is known to all who wear glasses (spectales), everyone who wears glasses has the temples adjusted, this imperfection in orientation of temples makes the glasses sit perfectly on the eyes.

I think it is fascinating that your ears can tell a direction of a sound within 1 degree in front of you based on the tiny amount of time it takes the nerve impulse from one ear over the other. within 10 microseconds the nerve impulse travels from one ear and reaches the olivary nucleus before the other ear which that center computes in your brain and you get a location.

What I love most about this video is that you are absolutely teaching proper gun safety. I had a wonderful Daddy like you! I grew up learning that a gun is a tool, a dangerous tool in the hands of an ignorant or impaired person. I'm older than dirt, so things were quite different when I was in school. In 10th Grade, I took a PE class on gun safety (this was public school in Texas). We never fired guns, but we were taught safety and hunting rules. Even showed us films on how to gut and dress game. Not fun to watch, but good to know for when the SHTF. There were no school shootings in those days. My Senior year, I was in the Drama Club, and we were doing a play set in WWI. My Dad had two old Italian sniper rifles (disabled, unable to fire) that I brought to school so they could be used as props. I walked in the front door of my HS in 1978, carrying those two rifles wrapped in a blanket. I stopped by the front admissions office to show them to an adult, I wanted them to see the firing pins were removed. (okay one minor quibble: As far as I can tell, we don't really know why dogs tilt their heads. There are several hypotheses, including that they do it especially when interacting with humans to get a better look at our face, since their muzzle gets in the way. Some research indicates that breeds with a large muzzle do this more than dogs with flatter faces. It's also possible that it's just a result of positive reinforcement, since dogs tilting their heads is so cute that humans always react positively.. Bottom line we don't know for sure, and it's likely that there are more than one reason. At least as far as I can tell..)

This video is a great and it also highlights the issue with binaural recordings. They are dependent on the head related transfer function of the wearer when recorded. This means the influence of our body, head, and ears. Which means this recording will work when played back for the person who recorded it but will have the same flaw you experienced with your son. Every person has a different head related transfer function so they will perceive left and right spatial sounds well but in front and back or anywhere along that vertical plane will be confused. Finally, your 3D sound videos will probably have a saving grace because our minds do a fantastic job of tricking our brains into spatial sound when the video reinforces the location.

When I was an engineering student, for a DSP course we had to try to generate sounds in MATLAB that appeared to come from any given direction. Doing it for the horizontal plane was relatively easy merely by using delays and low-pass filters. The only way to have any kind of success in the vertical plane however, was to apply a frequency response derived from recordings with a human head model with microphones in its ears. Even then, it only worked well for those persons whose ears were similar enough to the model…

Owls have exaggerated asymmetry to the placement of their ears which allows them to find their prey in the dark and under the dense cover.  The Great grey owl can even catch voles under the snow, strictly by the sound the vole is making.  We also have a slight asymmetry to our ears.  Check it out!  One ear is slightly more forward, and one is slightly higher than the other.  So it is not only the convolutions in your outer ear and the temporal difference but the spacing of your ears that allow you to pinpoint the source of a sound.  (But not as well as owls!)

binaural actually works, but not always in a great way, and here's why : you ears are as unique as you teeth prints or fingerprints. so they tweak the sound spectrum in a different way, and binaural is made to be as close to anybody's ears as it could, so it's the average that count. If your ears are very different, like a big and raised outer ear, it probably won't work great, and may results in strange soundscapes (like sounds coming from INSIDE you head instead of behind you, as I experienced, although my ears are pretty normal)

My theory on this is from studying night fighting. A cornerstone of martial arts defense. The technique is honed with closed eyes in darkness. Listening for the sound of an attackers movements interacting with the environment.
Sound at ground level won't echo at ground level. Yet bounce off further objects. Causing minute differences in timing.
While sounds originating from above will have more to echo off of. Also delaying acoustical return.
Therefore it is easier for the mind meat to calculate distance and altitude.

For an engineering project last year we were given four microphones and with those we had to make 'a source localiser'.  Indeed as was said during the video, we not only made use of the time difference of the sounds arriving between the microphones, another method was by analyzing the sound and extracting frequencies, and for several frequencies the theoretical scattering on a sphere (were we mounted the microphones on) were calculated and then in real time compared to the measured amplitude and phase differences between the microphones. Both methods gave good results. In the literature we found that the hearing of humans relies on the combination of all those things mentioned above and that the ear leads to a more difficult scattering but in which the direction is thus easier distinguished due to broken symmetry. I found this very interesting :)

I was born with only one ear, so I've never experienced true directional hearing.
I've always wanted to experience hearing in 3D like others do. The binuaral experience sounds amazing.

I do something similar to what an owl does for vision.

I cup my hand around my ear with an opening forward, and rotate my head until the sound is louder.

If anyone would like to try this out its pretty funny. Try playing an open world game of some sort like Fallout 4. Put only one earbud in and leave the other hanging. Of course make sure the TV plays no sound.

You'll have to constantly rotate your head to hear correctly.

Also try listening to music with one earbud. Depending on which one you're using you may only hear backup singers. A great example is the song Space Oddity.

This is what it's truly like to have one ear. Covering an ear doesn't give the same experience.

comment_by: UNACCEPTABLE One That Did The Stuff & Made A Video
comment_text:
I know all too much about this. I am a weekend warrior (hobbyist) sound man. When I was young, I ran sound systems for my own band and other's often. Did sound for church gigs too (youth events) and I was [still am cough cough] really good at it. Then when I was about 23 years old, I got a cold, not even a bad cold, but a head cold. I was stuffed up for about a week. I woke up that morning not feeling well and my ear felt like it was plugged. Like it was under water, I really wasn't feeling well. I went to work (installing satellite dishes) and after a short day went to emergency to get some antibiotics as my ear was really starting to hurt. That evening I went to bed at like 5pm not feeling well. I woke up about 7pm and the room was spinning so fast I couldn't sit up and started heaving everything that was in my stomach, and then everything that wasn't in my stomach!

My [right] inner ear died that day. Some "explainable" virus caused nerve damage. I spent 2 days on the couch and about 5 more in bed literally crawling to the bathroom eating nothing but a single piece of toast per day. Any movement of my head would send the room into a spin. I didn't leave the house for about 3 months because driving and looking around would make me sick to my stomach. It sucked.

Now being single sided deaf, I understand how much our brains really do on the fly with our "stereo inputs". Your eyes are the same. As far as hearing goes, by means described in your video your brain will also filter out unimportant noise. Things like background noise. When you are in a crowded room, like a restaurant, your brain will actually ignore everyone else automagically for you. For me, I can hear everyone at almost the same volume. It makes having a conversation very difficult.

Our eyes are similar, they, just like a camera, can not actually focus on a very large area at the same time, so most of what you "see" is actually made up by your brain. Your peripheral vision is actually just a bunch of blurry shapes. Clarity is added by your brain doing a really good job of making stuff up.

Keep up the good work, really loving the channel! Bonus points for making me stop and read at the end of each video.

Me and my dad have been arguing over this topic for ever. Our argument was about whether binaural microphones can capture not only the left and right of the sound source, but also the top, bottom, back and front. I was right to a certain degree since I thought you could never really know the height of the sound source under any circumstance, but my dad was also right to a smaller of a degree since he thought the opposite extreme of the spectrum; that not only can humans precisely tell where the sound is coming from, but you could also capture it with a pair of microphones. We both got some parts wrong in that humans ARE able to sense where the sound source is in all directions due to the complex systems involving the shape of the ears and the processing of the brain, and in that you need specially designed microphones (not just any) (like the 3Dio microphone - didn't think the design would theoretically enable vertical direction sensing until I saw this vid) to be able to record precise mapping of where the sound sources are coming from. I would say this is a very good example of what this channel can achieve: easily make me understand something I didn't even know how to start researching on. All I have left to do now is to forward this information to my dad! As always, thanks for the great video and please keep them coming.

Not sure if they still do this anymore, but a lot of car audio headunits utilized psychoacoustics to "raise the soundstage".  This makes your lower door speakers sound very much like they are up on the dash.  They then use time delays to trick your temporal awareness into thinking they are farther apart and/or equidistant as well.  Works fairly well, but it somehow reduces the quality of the sound.  Probably need more processing power.

Short tale to tell. A long time ago I was given a harmonica. At the time I was a telephone man and climbed poles every day, and every once in a while I would have to call in and would get put on hold, so I would take out my harmonica and start playing. What I noted was that people walking down the street, 18 feet below, would have a very hard time locating where the music was coming from. I discussed this with other people, including a prominent zoologist, and we came to the conclusion that humans are predators and have a tendency NOT to look up, as prey is usually on the ground.

awesome video ! I got my head used as a "template" for directional hearing modelization back in the late 90's at IRCAM (as an intern then). The results of the measurements are called HRTF, they are the physical filters generated by your skull, bones and hear to produce the 3D reference and training you've been very well explaining. Modern spatialization of sound in video games now use those. Simulating / faking sounds coming from the above are the most difficult to reproduce, as you can cheat on delays and basic filtering (my head filters were pretty "good" so to speak when applied to other people) for surround, but it comes to very specific personal physical properties when it comes to vertical hearing.
Spinning 15° per 15° for 2hrs in the anechoic chamber to get the measurements done were quite an experience, and your very nice video recalled me that, so thank you for this too.

comment_text: I actually think you can use temporal cues for vertical positioning as well. It's like having the leg and hypotenuse of a right triangle. You have a certain range of distance the leg can be (your brain won't know for sure though) and a certain range the hypotenuse could be. Applying the same philosophy as before, with focus on frequencies in addition to time and volume differences, your brain can still approximate the vertical difference if there isn't much obstructing noise. Of course, our ears are't quite that sensitive for our brains to be able to use those cues as well as they could for horizontal positioning. Not sure how true that actually is, but that's how i used to think about it, before I took into account the bouncing off of different parts of the ear idea, which obviously is much more accurate and decisive. I still think it's important to note though.

Another really cool example to look at here is the asymmetry in the ear canals in owl skulls -- one ear canal is tilted slightly upward, and the other slightly downward, so an owl can use its hearing to pinpoint a sound on a vertical axis as well as the horizontal. Very useful when you're catching mice in the dark while flying!
Fun fact. Owl ears are separated vertically to naturally achieve the same effect as dogs tilting their ears. Barn Owls can pinpoint prey in 3D space to incredible accuracy via sound alone.

Years ago, in the days of windows 98, I had an awesome sound card that could reproduce 3D audio pretty well. One of the features of the card's software was support for vertical orientation of sound sources using psychoacoustic algorithms. The test was the sound of a Helicopter circling you, you click a button to activate the vertical orientation and you can clearly hear the sound coming from above you. I have no idea how it works, but I assume they created a generalized way our pinna distort the sound and applied that distortion to the audio source.

Come to think of it, modeling this might actually be pretty easy. All you need is to make an artificial ear and stick a microphone where the ear drum would be. Play a test sound and use FFT to see how the ear construction affects the sound. Or take that recording and play it in earphones to see if you can tell where the sound is coming from... I would love to see that in a follow-up video!

Fascinating about the spectral cues. I feel smarter every day. As it happens, I learned an interesting thing about temporal cues when I took up SCUBA diving some years ago. I noticed that I found it very difficult to locate the direction of sound while under water. A boat would pass overhead and I couldn't tell whether it's towards the right or the left. Someone would bang on his cylinder to get my attention and I couldn't tell where the sound is coming from. For some reason my stereo hearing was completely wonky below the water.

Then I read up on it a little, and got smarter every day. Turns out that the reason for this is that sound waves travel much faster through water than through air. As a result, the waves from a sound emanating from the right would hit my left ear drum much sooner after it hits my right ear drum than it would when traveling through a less dense medium such as air, which diminishes my brain's ability to resolve the directionality of the source.

Many years ago I was fascinated by this subject and hypothesised to myself that resolution of the third dimension of sound was to do with our ability to sense the spectral colouring of the audio signal reaching the "business" part of the ear introduced by the physical detail and surfaces of the pina. Furthermore, I hypothesised a design for ear phones that could replicate true three dimensional sound for say gaming or the hard of hearing, that could reproduce this spectral content. I am of the opinion that since the dimensions of the details of the pina are in the order of millimetres, then a resolution of around 10 microseconds (or 100khz frequency response) would be required to reproduce this information for dissemination by the auditory system.
Due to lack of resources however, I was unable to develop prove my theory or develop any such devices.
Recently there have been a number of "binaural" presentations which purport to demonstrate three dimensional sound. All of these using the standard audio systems including the head phones. And all of these, for me, although able to give an "intimate" sence of presence, nevertheless fail to give clear up/down, front/back resolution. In fact it's more as if the sound emirates from between the ears or inside the head. I believe that our auditory system, whilst not consciously "hearing" these frequencies (20-100khz), is able to "sence" them and decode the information into a sence of direction. I would maintain that an audio reproduction system with a high frequency response of up to 100khz is necessary to replicate true three dimensional sound.
I would be very grateful if someone could spare me some time to comment on this. .

I was working as a subcontractor for Soundlab Speakers with Roger West and his son Brett throughout the 90s.  We were always looking at new technologies in the audio reproduction world.  Bose had come out with a speaker system that simulated surround sound for home theaters using two speakers and a computer program that made spectral modifications for each virtual audio channel.  Because each of your ears are completely asymmetrical top to bottom front to back and inside to outside, Bose had figured out some average spectral modifications to make to the sound as it came through each channel in order to simulate a 5:1 or 7:1 surround sound system.  What they were missing though was a calibration function to try and dial in those modifications to create a better experience.  Anyway, I thought that was a pretty cool application of this concept.

@SmarterEveryDay - one factor you could have mentioned is that as we age, our high frequency hearing ability decreases.  Add in exposure to loud noises (eg music via earbuds or headphones, or gunfire, industrial noise etc) and you lose pretty much ALL high frequency hearing.  BUT - and this is the big one - it is the HIGH frequencies that provide us with the ability to localise sound.  Lower frequencies are omnidirectional (that's why your subwoofer can be under the couch).  SO - someone with high frequency hearing loss not only has difficulty hearing, but also has great difficulty in localising sound.  The worst thing you can do when someone with a high frequency hearing loss calls out "Where are you?" is to reply "Here"...!

Ground reflections. When audio engineers talk about reverb as an effect, one of the settings is called early reflections. Early reflections are the sounds you hear first in natural reverb and they are the sounds that allow you to determine the size of the space you are occupying. If a source of sound is close to the ground you will hear the early reflections at a volume that you would not hear when the source is up high.  Google the "Haas Effect" if you want more detail.

Immediately, I started wondering how long it takes a person to recalibrate. When you alter the channels like that, it doesn't change the fact that sound changes depending on which part of the ear it hits first; it just alters the way that sound changes. So, presumably, one could learn these new changes.
The question is, could one learn them before one has to remove the play-dough, and return to life as usual. Because obviously you can't go through life with play-dough jammed in your ear cartilage, and the shape of the play-dough will definitely change from one application to the next.

So, way back in the early 80’s, when pagers started getting popular, I was on call with my employer one weekend. When the battery weakened, the pager would start beeping. Well, I carried the thing in my back pocket and it started beeping. I, unaccustomed to the beeping sound, started looking for it in my house. My wife and best friend was looking for the source of the sound too. I thought it must be originating from the attic of our house, but as I walked around trying to find it, they said it was moving. After not finding the source of the sound in the attic, I decided that it had to be coming from the outside, and went passed the other two on my way out. They found it when I walked by but they didn’t catch me before I got outside. The sound eluded me, even outside, until they told me, and I found the source in my back pocket. My pager! I have never forgot the sound. To this day, the beep-beep-beep of the pager is branded on my brain.

Works great until you lose 20+dB in hearing on one side after waking up and yawning one morning, suddenly you find yourself in a world without that same stereo directivity.  Yet, if I had lost 20dB in both ears equally I would still be able to use those directional cues effectively.  It has really curtailed enjoyment of music since everything sounds largely monophonic due to the sensitivity imbalance between left and right.

This is fascinating to me for several reasons: 1) I am severely hearing-impaired and have lost the ability to place where sounds are coming from even though the pinna on both of my ears are undamaged. 2) I had a hearing assistance dog for many years, and she would help me locate where my children were when they would play outside. (We live on 4.5 acres of wooded property, so getting a visual on them was nearly impossible for me.) I remember how she would tilt her head when I commanded her to go find them! Now I know why. 3) Even though my hearing loss is hereditary, my son has excellent hearing and is currently pursuing a degree in audio engineering and media arts. I plan on forwarding this to him; I'm sure he'll find it intriguing as well. And, I would love to subscribe to Audible, but it just doesn't work out for me for obvious reasons. I've heard a different explanation for why dogs tilt their heads.  Apparently tilting their head makes it easier for them to see something in front of them, because usually their snout blocks their vision a little bit.  This is supported by the fact that dogs with longer snouts are more likely to head-tilt.  Dogs with short snouts do it a little bit as well, because they do it by chance and then get positive reinforcement from their owners, who think it looks cute.

Owls have a similar thing to dogs, except instead of tilting their heads they actually have asymmetrical ear holes - one ear is higher up their skull than the other ear. Sound is a big part of their hunting, and of course given they're flying predators being able to tell where something is on the vertical plane is really important for them.

The difference between what your left and right ears hear is known as the Head Related Transfer Function (HRTF). As you correctly identified, the head will act as a low-pass filter, blocking higher frequencies at the more distant ear. This is basic psychoacoustics stuff, but it's quite a specialized field. As a mechanic for decades I will search for engine noises from two perspectives or sometimes three. First, from the front of the car I can tell if the sound is coming from the left or right. Then I'll move to the side, and try to determine the left-right perspective again, which will help me hear if it's from the front, center or rear of the engine and then cross those lines. Sometimes I'll tilt my head to hear if it's high or low in the engine compartment. I've done this for as long as I can remember. Also visually, to get my hand held drill straight with the work I'll look at it from two perspectives or get a helper to stand 90 degrees from my perspective and tell me when it's perpendicular with the work, and I get the holes drilled exceptionally straight this way. I've always been aware of the left right bias and turning my head like a dog to get the vertical bias. Interesting to me that- a lot of people don't notice this since a little kid I've done this.

I have a so-called mild hearing impairment called "otosclerosis", which means the sound waves get a little distorted as they pass through the middle ear. This distortion usually lowers the pitch very similarly to CB radio distortions, which is frustrating enough as it is when listening to music. What makes it worse for me is that my right side is affected about 30% more than my left side, so quite often I get this echo effect; but I can't tell where the sound is coming from unless I turn and/or tilt my head. I have found that cupping my ears with my hands from behind can help to amplify directional sounds.

One thing that is really cool is trying to detect the high-pitched call notes of fledgling songbirds.  I do breeding bird surveys a couple of months each year, and it is really amazing how deceptive some of the higher, metallic "tink" calls can be.  These are really small birds (warblers, vireos, sparrows), and the young blend in very well in the leafy cover of the forest. As you explored in this video, I am able to pinpoint them pretty quickly left to right, forward to back...but I really struggle with that spectral-altitude aspect when I get in close.   They are great ventriloquists!  Sometimes the bird seems to be about chest-high off of the forest floor, and they end up being twenty feet over my head...or vice versa.  So cool.  I really enjoy your explorations!  Keep up the great work!

Without some level of training [formal or not] telling relative elevation by sound alone is nearly impossible. You can use stereo headphones and simulated spaces to train your ears for elevation, and if that is to expensive you could always use surround sound and 3d audio settings in video games one PC. Windows has 5.1 surround and 3D sound built-in and some titles take advantage of this feature. Note that results may vary and perception of elevation is typically not as accurate as perception of direction. At best you can expect trinary perception of elevation [above inline or below]

In short, dogs have extremely directional ears, "at price of" very non-linear spectral response. They would make for terrible musician or piano tuner ;-)
BTW, you know how high freq, let's say above 10kHz, get completely blocked by your head, so you hear them at just one side, (unles they bounce from a wall/flat object into another ear).
The higher the frequency, the more directional and higher gain the same size antenna (uhm, or like ear) can be.
So dogs can hear much higher frequencies, and a rotable pointy ear of dog has like really, really narrow directivity at near ultrasound frequencies.
They often tend to rotate each ear in opposite direction, if they can, since they are so directional at ultra high frequencies, they hear basically nothing if not pointing their ear directly at sound source (or its echo). And those ultra high frequencies provide most accurate direction information.
I have seen, well heard, my dog catching mosqitoes and flies in pitch black, at rate over one per minute (i wanted her to go to sleep and stop jumping on the bed to catch them, so i turned off EVERYTHING that had a LED/light). I know she was successfull, as they were no more ;-)

Some how despite not having both ears for triangulation she must be getting some data from the one working ear or her guesses would be random.

Hey Destin (and other viewers),

Audio/theatre engineer here. Thought i'd share something interesting in relation to this video's subject. Psychoacoustics is also used in theatre and festivals. The goal most of the time is to amplify the sound from someone or something on stage naturally, so we want the amplified sound to come from the direction that the person or thing is. The way this is done with speakers on the front of the stage faced at the audience, but (most of the time) we cant put speakers in front of that, because it would block the view! So instead we place the speakers on the side and above the opening of the stage. Here comes the trick: we can use slight delays to trick the audiences brain into thinking the sound comes from another place because with one speaker delayed the other speakers sound will reach the audience earlier thereby shifting perception of location. Also in regards to vertical sensing of sound, because human ears don't hear vertically very well (as you proved) it doesn't matter that much of the speakers are higher up above the stage. Hope you find this interesting, If there are any questions let me know.

TL;DR - A .22 LR has a terminal speed of <= 57.5 m/s or 189 ft/s

A lot of people seem to be debating the danger of a falling .22LR bullet. Let's do some basic analysis:
In equilibrium, we have m*g = 1/2*Cd*A*ρ*v^2 for v the terminal speed.
v = √(2m*g/(Cd*A*ρ))

A solid lead .22LR has mass 40 gr or 2.6 g. At 9.81 N/kg, it exerts 25 mN of weight. This is an upper bound, and many rounds weigh less.
The falling bullet has a Reynolds number of about 40,000 (Re = ρvL/μ) so approximating as a sphere, its Cd is 0.5.
2r = .223" so r = .1115" = 2.83mm. A = πr^2 = 25.2 mm^2. Air density at STP is ρ = 1.225 kg/m^3.

We obtain v = 57.5 m/s = 189 ft/s
KE = 1/2*m*v^2 = 4.3J = 3.2 ft*lb

The approximations used here are conservative and yield a higher speed than in reality. The drag on the real bullet will be more than for a smooth sphere of the same radius due to the square base, surface roughness, and tumbling.

SmarterEveryDay So, here's why I think this video is both a good example of safe gun handling practices and a good illustration of why the only safe way to handle guns is to not handle them:

Obviously Destin and his family are trained in how to handle guns properly. That part gets a big plus. However, even with that knowledge, as soon as the drone was tumbling down towards the ground, the shooter forgot a very important rule: safe the rifle before moving .

Destin caught it immediately and took command which was excellent, but it still only takes one moment of inattention combined with something else to accidentally fire the gun.

And this is with at least one trained adult around . Accidents happen because even the best of us get careless or lose focus at times. Life is a series of trade-offs. Some risks we accept because they are necessary for a normal life: we take a small but calculated risk every time we drive to work. We take a risk when we slice our bread. We take a risk whenever we play sports or go swimming or take a bike ride.

And we take risks every time we handle a loaded firearm. For most people this is an unacceptable risk, because the gain from it is little to none. For people in the country who hunt or have to manage their land, it might be a necessary tool. Likewise for law enforcement officers and military personnel.

Over one thousand kids die from gunshot wounds every year in the US. Five times as many are injured. Even taking into account the large number of people in the US, those are unfathomable numbers for most people in other developed nations. In the US, it is simply "the cost of doing business", metaphorically speaking.

Each and every case is of course a huge, huge tragedy for the families involved. Were some of those guns necessary? Absolutely. Were all of them? Absolutely not. Were most of them? I don't know, but I seriously doubt it.

I have no good solution to what is certainly a systemic problem in the US society - almost exactly as many people die from gunshot wounds each year as die in traffic, around 34,000 people or 10.5-10.6 per 100,000 population. (And keep in mind that the death rates in traffic are between 2-4 times higher in the US than in most comparable developed nations, so that's a whole different problem all unto itself.)

I am sure Destin and his family are very responsible gun owners. But owning guns moves the risk of an accident from zero to non-zero. Only they can make the judgement whether that risk is worth it to them or not.

Ive thought about this a lot! How we can hear up and down. Now i understand how the sound is differs because of the shape of our ears BUT if you hear a certain sound for the first time, how do you know it's coming from up or down? Your brain can't compare it to the same sound but lower or higher from your position.
So would say boxers or UFC fighters that have developed cauliflower ears have a hard time with positional audio or would their brain be able to adapt over time?

I am an audio engineer, and work in the studio all the time, I LOVE psychoacoustics. There's so, soooo much information packed into what we perceive as sound, and learning how to unpack it, analyse it, and manipulate it is one of the craziest things to me.

The goal of a good mix engineer is to be able to take any sound, and just using a stereo monitoring set up (either speakers in front of you in a mix position, or headphones) be able to put a sound anywhere in a 3 dimensional environment using frequency, volume, and temporal effects (delay and reverb).

One of my favorite parts about all of this craziness is the WAY your brain tells you the information. It's not conscious cues once you start getting down to minute changes. You have to start listening to your emotional responses to things. Once you start changing 0.5 dB or less, you'll "feel" different about it, but you usually can't consciously hear the difference.

And all of this isn't even getting in to the use of delays and reverberant sound to tell you cues about the shape, size, and texture of the material of a room, and the sound source's location in the room compared to you :-). Your brain does a thousand things every time you process sound, then sums it up in to a neat little presentation for you.

Hi !
Just to say that I have a bluetooth headset to listen my music. On it, there is a button to mute the music and activate the microphone. It gives you the ability to ear around you without having to remove your headset. But it is really confusing for your brain and it's not really useful, there is why :
- people doesn't understand that you can ear them when you activate the microphone
- you can also remove your headset, it pauses your music automatically ><
-The microphone is on a single channel, so you lose your stereo and spatial localisation
-The microphone is pretty sensitive and you can ear farther with the same level than you usually do

So when I activate the microphone, I have to "relearn" quickly the way I hear and be more careful to danger and other stuff if I'm walking on the street.

I don't think that's why dogs tilt their head. Not all dogs tilt their head.. and the ones that do, don't do it all the time! Plus when they do it, they already know the source of the sound (more often than not a person talking to them). My theory is that they tilt their head when they hear something that excites them.
I have two dogs and only one of them tilts his head regularly.. and It's usually when I'm talking to him and I say a word or phrase that he knows and gets excited about.. like "wanna go" "let's go" "eat" "park"... but if I'm only doing it to get him to tilt his head, he catches on pretty quickly and loses interest and stops doing it!
Other noises make him tilt his head too.. like squeaky toys, insects, tv, ringtones.. but he always knows the source of the sound! and finally, the first time that he saw a flame from a lighter, he tilted his head left and right like 5 times.. so I really think it's the curiosity and excitement and not to improve hearing!

As an audio engineer I have studied psychoacoustics extensively. There are 3 things that effect sound localisation (you missed one). These are interaural frequency difference (IFD), your head casts an acoustic 'shadow.' Interaural time difference (ITD) your brain can detect the 0.0006 second delay between your ears from a sound that is 90 degrees to your head. And lastly interaural level differences (ILD). As you double your distance from a sound you lower it's level by 6dB. The average distance between your ears is 21.5cm therefore if a sound occurs 21.5cm away from your right ear at 90 degrees to your head then by the time it reaches your left ear it will have doubled its distance and your left ear will hear the sound 6dB quieter. Add in the IFD and ITD and you can easily localise sound. This goes out the window when a sound is equidistant from your ears i.e. It is in front or behind you. There is no time, frequency or level difference and we therefore rely upon the pinna. The fact that the pinna blocks sound from behind you makes front to back localisation relatively easy but vertical localisation is much harder. As you correctly explained it is done via the concha, helix and antihelix. The sound reflections off of these parts of the outer ear have roughly a 0.00002 second delay between them and your brain can distinguish these and use them to locate the sound. But, this is not particularly accurate leading to the struggle to locate sound in this plane. Our ability to localise sound to our sides is by far the strongest with IFD, ITD, ILD and the Pinna (in that order of effectiveness) all working together. Whereas vertical localisation is reliant solely on the pinna leading to the inaccuracy.

Brilliant! An additional aspect for head-tilting in dogs may be binocular. Notice that dogs also look intently while tilting their heads. Binocular vision gives visual clues about depth location, but only if the pattern of images from both eyes 'compute' the differences because visual details about angular recognition can be distinguished from 'left' to 'right' between the eyes at their orientation. This also can be demonstrated with an experiment.
Look at anything that would not look different from one eye to the other; for instance, look at a wire that's strung horizontally between power or telephone poles, but without the poles being within your visual field. The image of the wire in each eye will be the same when your head is level, and you won't be able to distinguish its distance from you unless you tilt your head. When you tilt your head, the angular difference between the images in your eyes gives the visual clues needed for depth perception. Humans and dogs evolved as predators that needed to see & distinguish prey & other predators from a large distance while also needing to calculate that distance visually. On the other hand, ambush predators like cats rely more on auditory range-finding because they get close to their prey before pouncing, so they don't rely on visual clues with head-tilting.

This reminded me of something I learned from a neuroethology course years ago, back in college, just to expand a bit on the horizontal location of sound:

One theory of how we could decipher horizontal location of sound is that our insular lobes of the brain (the part under the "side folds" of our temporal lobes) have entire areas with individual neurons designated to sounds of specific pitch and location. The timing differential from our two ears means that sound is picked up and interpreted by either ears at different time, creating a time lag. Each of the location neurons is a sort of "AND gate", where the two sounds from both ears must be picked up at the exact same time for it to be triggered. For instance, there would be neurons for 1 millisecond time lag, another for 2, and still another for 5, and so on. Each neuron is also mapped to a region in space, which is then interpreted as sound coming from a horizontal area.

This didn't explain vertical location, though, which is something explored by your video. Now I wonder if you could experiment next time with tilting your head to locate a vertical sound source with playdough padding your ears.

BTW, owl automatically do the "doggy head tilt" thing, in a way, since their left and right ear canals point in opposite directions (one up, one down) to help with vertical location.

This is a really interesting area! Some random thoughts:

- The spectral cues filter sounds before you reach your ears, modifying the spectrum, but if you don't know what the original spectrum of the sound was, how can you tell how it was modified in order to localise it? You can't! You need to have some familiarity with the sounds that you're hearing for this to work.

- In order to be able to hear the effect of the filter, the sounds need to have frequencies that the filtering effects, so it only works with broadband sounds. If you try playing a 1kHz sine wave from a speaker, you will find it hard to localize compared to noise.

- As well as the pinna, reflections from your shoulders give height information.

- It's interesting to think about where the spectral filtering comes from, as it shows the duality between time domain impulse responses and frequency responses of systems. As well as hearing sound that has travelled directly from the source to your ears, you also hear sound that has reflected off of things, like your pinna and shoulders. What you hear is the sum of the direct sound and all the reflections. Because sound takes time to travel, each of these reflections is delayed by some amount. Considering a sine wave, if you add it to itself with a delay equal to half the wavelength, the peaks line up with the troughs, and it cancels out, so you get a dip in the frequency response at that frequency. The amount that this happens changes with the frequency, so a single reflection creates a "comb filter", with equally spaced frequencies that cancel out.

The stereo hearing and stereo sighting just shows that we, humans, are a predatory species.

Having grown up in southern Africa, we were taught from an early age how to use the 5 'S' system, which was used in the bush war against camouflaged insurgents. I'll explain. As soon as you pointed the camera at the tree I spotted the drone. Hearing is one thing, but vision is just as important. By seeing an unusual Shape compared to the relatively uniform pattern of the layout of the branches, I will focus my attention on that object. In this case it was enough to see the drone. Size confirms shape as to the object being out of place. Silhouette against contre jour or any global light is very important to note, as in foliage, the light normally passes through leaves, grass etc and it's only fully blocked by solid objects such as trunks, rocks and creatures. Sometimes the object is not directly visible, but it's Shadow may give away its location. Closely related to Shape is Structure. The difference being that rather than noticing that a shape is out of place which can be an automatic recognition, Structure evaluates the shape to determine its nature, whether natural or man made, friend or foe etc, etc. Hunters with so called 'eagle eyes' have simply practiced the above until it's just second nature...

On their own, these things seem obvious, but it's amazing how much we look at and do not see.

hey destin you talked about the Head-related transfer function for vertical localization and Interaural time difference for horizontal localization. but there is another way we do sound localisation. Interaural time difference are only used for low frequency sounds, for higher frequencies we use Interaural intensity/level difference. Higher frequency sound will have lower intensity at one ear compared to the other due to the head shadow effect, while time/phase differerences are too small to be usefull.
